details.title: Optimal age-replacement policy for nonrepairable products under renewing free-replacement warranty

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Ind. Manage., Nat. Taiwan Univ. of Sci. & Technol., Taipei, Taiwan

p: Ruey Huei Yeh is currently a full professor with the Department of Industrial Management at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, and was awarded Distinguished Young Industrial Engineer in 1999 by the Chinese Institute of Industrial Engineers. He received both his M.S. and Ph.D. in Industrial and Operations Engineering from the University of Michigan—Ann Arbor, and his B.S. in Industrial Engineering from the National Tsing-Hua University, Taiwan. His research interests include reliability theory, applied probability, warranty cost analysis, and quality management.

authors.name: R.H. Yeh

p: Gaung-Cheng Chen received his B.S. in Business Mathematics from Soochow University, Taiwan, and his M.S. degree in Statistics from National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan. He obtained his Ph.D. degree in Industrial Management from the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology (Taiwan) in 2003. He is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Commerce Automation and Management, Chihlee Institute of Technology, Taiwan. His research areas include reliability theory, warranty policies, decision analysis, and supply chain management.

Ming-Yuh Chen is currently a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Industrial Management at the National Taiwan University of Science and Technology. His research areas include reliability theory, warranty cost analysis, and production scheduling.

details.abstract: This paper investigates the effects of a renewing free-replacement warranty on the age replacement policy for a nonrepairable product. For both warranted, and nonwarranted products, cost models are developed, and the corresponding optimal replacement ages are derived such that the long-run expected cost rate is minimized. Furthermore, we show that the optimal replacement age for a warranted product is closer to the end of the warranty period than for a nonwarranted product. Finally, numerical examples are given to evaluate the impact of a product warranty on the optimal replacement age.

references.title: Replacement costs under warranty: Cost moments and time variability

context.text: Mathematical formulation, and cost evaluation for the free-replacement warranty policy have been investigated analytically in [1], [8], [12].

references.text: Y. Balcer, I. Sahin, "Replacement costs under warranty: Cost moments and time variability", Oper. Res., vol. 34, pp. 554-559, 1986.

references.title: Mathematical Theory of Reliability

context.text: After Barlow & Proschan [2] have systematically studied the age replacement policy, the variations of this policy have been investigated intensively for various situations, and many analytical results have been obtained [3], [4], [9], [11].

references.text: R. E. Barlow, F. Proschan, Mathematical Theory of Reliability, 1965.

references.title: A proof of optimality for age replacement policies

context.text: After Barlow & Proschan [2] have systematically studied the age replacement policy, the variations of this policy have been investigated intensively for various situations, and many analytical results have been obtained [3], [4], [9], [11].

references.text: M. Berg, "A proof of optimality for age replacement policies", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 13, pp. 751-759, 1976.

references.title: Comparison of age, block, and failure replacement policies

context.text: After Barlow & Proschan [2] have systematically studied the age replacement policy, the variations of this policy have been investigated intensively for various situations, and many analytical results have been obtained [3], [4], [9], [11].

links.abstract: Two widely used preventive replacement policies are the age replacement policy (ARP) and the block replacement policy (BRP). Another replacement policy is the failure replacement policy (FRP) in which no preventive replacements are made at all. In this paper we give a rule for choosing the least costly of the above three policies under conditions specified in the paper. The implementation of this rule is illustrated for two special cases, where the distribution of item life times is uniform, or ...

references.text: M. Berg, B. Epstein, "Comparison of age block and failure replacement policies", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 27, pp. 25-29, 1978.

references.title: Product warranty management&#821I: A taxonomy for warranty policies

context.text: A detailed discussion & review of various issues related to product warranty can be found in work by Blischke & Murthy [5]–[7].
For nonrepairable products, the most commonly used warranty policy is the renewing free-replacement warranty [5].

references.text: W. R. Blischke, D. N. P. Murthy, "Product warranty management̵I: A taxonomy for warranty policies", Eur. J. Oper. Res., vol. 62, pp. 127-148, 1992.

references.title: Comparisons of renewable warranties

context.text: Furthermore, Mi [10], and Ritchken & Fuh [13] further incorporate product warranty with various maintenance actions to evaluate the expected warranty cost.

references.title: A note on age replacement

context.text: After Barlow & Proschan [2] have systematically studied the age replacement policy, the variations of this policy have been investigated intensively for various situations, and many analytical results have been obtained [3], [4], [9], [11].

links.abstract: This note discusses more explicitly an age replacement policy suggested by Barlow and Proschan and gives a few useful results. It shows that several different problems can be reduced to the typical age replacement problem, and gives numerical examples.

references.text: S. S. Osaki, T. Nakagawa, "A note on age replacement", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 24, pp. 92-94, 1975.

references.title: Warranty policies for nonrepairable items under risk aversion

context.text: Mathematical formulation, and cost evaluation for the free-replacement warranty policy have been investigated analytically in [1], [8], [12].

links.abstract: An approach is presented for analyzing full replacement and linear prorated warranty policies for items receiving renewable warranties when failure occurs during the warranty interval. The model corrects a model of Thomas and then extends the methodology by describing how sellers' risk aversity influences the policy. For constant failure intensities, linear replacement policies are more attractive to risk averse sellers than shorter term full replacement policies that result in the same average ...

references.text: P. H. Ritchken, "Warranty policies for nonrepairable items under risk aversion", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 34, pp. 147-150, 1985.

references.title: Optimal replacement policies for irreparable warranted items

context.text: Furthermore, Mi [10], and Ritchken & Fuh [13] further incorporate product warranty with various maintenance actions to evaluate the expected warranty cost.

links.abstract: This article investigates age replacement policies for irreparable items sold under warranty. Since the costs of replacement depends on terms of warranty, the analysis of age replacement policies is more complex. Optimal age replacement policies that minimize the long run average cost rate are constructed. For warrantied items with increasing failure rates, the optimal policy is to replace functioning items after a finite period of time. A few examples are presented to illustrate the theory.

references.text: P. H. Ritchken, D. Fuh, "Optimal replacement policies for irreparable warranted items", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 35, pp. 621-623, 1986.

references.title: Optimum warranty policies for nonreparable items

links.abstract: An approach is presented for establishing and evaluating warranty policies for products receiving renewable warranties when failure occurs during warranty. A general rebate model is described that allows total compensation to a consumer for failures during a fixed period and prorated compensation for a remaining interval of time. Associated warranty costs are weighed against the s-expected benefit to be derived from the program. Conditions for optimum warranty intervals are provided. Closed form...

references.text: M. U. Thomas, "Optimum warranty policies for nonreparable items", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. 32, pp. 282-288, 1983.
